Link: Antivirus for Linux - Bitdefender Antivirus Scanner for Unices

Go To this link and choose 'Request a Free License (for personal use only)' from left hand side menu. You have to fill a form for license and they will send you a key and location to download anti-virus for your system.

After downloading:

Open terminal and go to location where you downloaded.

Make executable and change permission (You can use full name also I used asterisk alternatively)

chmod u+x BitDefender-Antivirus-Scanner*
Install (You can use full name also I used asterisk alternatively)

sudo ./BitDefender-Antivirus-Scanner*
The License page will open in terminal. Keep pressing space-bar till you reach end and than it will ask you to ACCEPT it. Just write

accept
And Press ENTER

Finally it will ask if you want to install GUI pack as well. Write

y
And press enter

Run it like any other application on Ubuntu. When you open it there will be an option to 'SET A NEW KEY' press it and copy the key you got in E-mail.

Bit-defender will be up and running with an year license and don't forget to Update it. There is an option in program to do so automatically.

@dragon788 I'm on GNU/Linux, after wasting way too many hours trying to compile it on my Windows based office computer (Windows sucks!)
Already pulled in libgit2 and libssh2.

The configure steps I ran and that lead to those error messages above (after attempting to make libgit2. No error messages on building libssh2):

Inside the libssh2 root directory:
```
 ./configure --host=x86_64-w64-mingw32
```



Inside libgit2/build:

```
cmake .. -DCMAKE_C_COMPILER=x86_64-w64-mingw32-gcc -DCMAKE_SYSTEM_NAME=Windows -DCMAKE_RC_COMPILER=`which x86_64-w64-mingw32-windres` -DDLLTOOL=`which x86_64-w64-mingw32-dlltool` -DCMAKE_FIND_ROOT_PATH=/usr/x86_64-w64-mingw32 -DCMAKE_FIND_ROOT_PATH_MODE_INCLUDE=ONLY
```
you may need to install some -dev packages to get the right pieces to get it to compile cleanly

Having lived the Windows  everlasting apoclypse of creating more and more complexity and seeing how things break in server environments because KISS and a Zen like philosophy was not followed leaving MS at a point where they will have to spend billions to recreate it one or another time without backwards compatibility and being able to service even handheld devices properly I see a possible disaster coming. I do however do not know enough of the deep technical stuff of Linux to make a call. Out of simple experience in the infrastructure environment and having had the "joy" of living through that for 27 years of my life I would like to create a development environment that will adhere to KISS, be secure and not interdependent on a component that is not modular and if broken can and will take the whole system down defeating the purpose for which Linux was famous for mission critical systems that does not need to be rebooted when a new driver or fix come out. Simplicity is elegance and quick fixes is not the answer to that even if everybody likes it or it was democraticaly decided. Hello.

without knowing more, I'll assume that you installed it in such a way that basically the iso was just copied to the thumb drive, which makes it a read only file system, so you can't write to it. You basically need to use core plus it's the easiest way to get everything working. You can also do this... accoring to the FAQ if one insists on using a third party installation tool and one that does not officially support Core and thereby copies the entirety of the TinyCore iso then you are faced with manual setup of either creating a second partition for your tce dir, or renaming the cde to tce thus indicating that this is not a CD and editing the syslinux.cfg changing cde to waitusb=5 to indicate that is a pendrive.

It is not recommended to have a cde directory on any live working system. The whole point of modularity is the ability to easily upgrade the X/GUI extension separate from the base Core.

Therefore in the case of unetbootin renaming cde to tce is required.

also, when executing a program from the command line, many linux distros don't search the current folder when looking for the program to execute.  You may need to add `./` before the program name eg. `./node`

@tzchrzanowski executable files in linux usually don't use extensions to indicate that they are executable.  They are executable because of file permissions

NTFS is either inconsistent, or there is a hardware fault, or it's a
SoftRAID/FakeRAID hardware. In the first case run chkdsk /f on Windows
then reboot into Windows twice. The usage of the /f parameter is very
important! If the device is a SoftRAID/FakeRAID then first activate
it and mount a different device under the /dev/mapper/ directory, (e.g.
/dev/mapper/nvidia_eahaabcc1). Please see the 'dmraid' documentation
for more details.

If no one had written Git, we'd be using the (arguably) inferior Mercurial, and my argument is that we would have seen a very similar paradigm shift, with very similar GitHub-like tools appearing (maybe a MercurHub? who knows), and I'm just surprised to have Git cited at the same level of contribution from Linus to the world as the Linux kernel.

Git came out roughly *at the same time* as Mercurial and other thing. And while it was a paradigm shift, I never considered it a revolution brought on by Linus. I'm saying I was not expecting it to be in the video, I'm not trying to disrespect Linus or anyone else.

Got motivated to upgrade kernel to 4.4 with Ubuntu 14.04. Turns out to be fairly simple - here are the links I used to guide my upgrade

```bash
$ apt-cache search linux-image # find the kernel you want

$ sudo apt-get install linux-image-your_version_choice-generic
$ sudo apt-get install linux-image-extra-your_version_choice-generic
$ sudo apt-get install linux-headers-your_version_choice-generic
```

- [install latest kernel with apt](https://askubuntu.com/questions/119080/how-to-update-kernel-to-the-latest-mainline-version-without-any-distro-upgrade)
- [remove old kernels](https://help.ubuntu.com/community/Lubuntu/Documentation/RemoveOldKernels#Safely_removing_old_kernels): remove image, image-extra, and headers for each version
